metadata.title: Cryo-electron microscopy structure of the SADS-CoV spike glycoprotein 1 provides insights into an evolution of unique coronavirus spike proteins 2 3

abstract.text: The outbreak of a novel betacoronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) has aroused great 28 public health concern. As a new coronavirus which was responsible for a 29 large-scale outbreak of fatal disease in piglets in China, swine acute diarrhea 30 syndrome coronavirus (SADS-CoV) originated from the same genus of 31 horseshoe bats (Rhinolophus) as SARS-CoV and possesses a broad species 32 tropism. In addition to human cells, it can also infect cell lines from diverse 33 species. Given the importance of the spike glycoprotein (S) protein in viral 34 entry and host immune responses, here we report the cryo-EM structure of the 35 SADS-CoV S in the prefusion conformation at a resolution of 3.55 Å. Our 36 studies reveal that SADS-CoV S structure takes an intra-subunit quaternary 37 packing mode where the NTD and CTD from the same subunit pack together 38 by facing each other. The comparison of NTD and CTD with that of the other 39 four genera gives the suggestion of the evolutionary procedure of the 40 SADS-CoV S. Moreover, SADS-CoV S has several characteristic structural 41 features, i.e., more compact architecture of S trimer, masking of epitopes by 42 glycan shielding, which may facilitate to viral immune evasion. These data 43 provide new insights into the evolutionary relationships of SADS-CoV S and 44 would deepen our understanding of their structural and functional diversity 45 which will facilitate to vaccine development.

body_text.text: They have shared features of pathogenicity, origin from bats [1] [2] [3] . Generally, 55 CoVs viral particles have a crown-like shape from which they are termed after. 56 The genome of CoV is the second largest of all RNA viruses containing a receptor-binding domain (RBD) viral attachment and entry subunit S1 (~700 86 amino acids) forming a crown like structure and a membrane-fusion C-terminal 87 subunit S2 (~600 amino acids) leading to an assembly of architecture i.e., CTD 88 is sandwiched by its NTD [16] . In addition, CTDs with assistance of S1 retain a 89 "lying down" inactive state which transits to "stand up" active state on the S 90 trimer for efficient receptor binding [17] [18] [19] [20] .

The envelope trimeric S protein is vital for identifying host tropism and 92 transmission limit. It intercedes receptor binding to approach host cell cytosol 93 utilizing acid-dependent proteolytic cleavage of S protein by a cathepsin, 94 TMPRRS2, or additional protease ensued by fusion of the membrane [21, 22] .

CoVs utilize an assortment of receptors and triggers to enact fusion [14] . 96 Receptor binding is fundamental to host-pathogen interaction and 97 pathogenesis. Numerous α-CoVs, for example, human CoV (HCoV-229E), is an essential need for primary and practical comprehension of SADS-CoV to 106 additionally expand mechanisms of viral entry and pathogenesis in pigs.

Notwithstanding the significance of the S protein in viral entry and host 108 immunity, high-resolution structural details of this enormous macromolecular 109 machine have been hard to acquire. In this study, a cryo-EM structure of 110 SADS-CoV S glycoprotein at 3.55 Å resolution is determined. Correspondingly 111 in the present investigation of SADS-CoV, we portrayed the general structure 112 of the S protein and the organization of its structural components. In light of the structures and functions of these essential components, we detail the 114 evolutionary perspective of SADS-CoV S in comparison with S proteins from 115 different CoV genera. In our study, SADS-CoV S forms a "lying down" 116 conformation following transition from inactive to active state and ACE2 is not HR-C (Fig. 1D, Fig. S3 ). Forty-five (15 on each subunit) N-linked glycans 148 spread over the surface of whole S trimer with another 15 predicted but not 149 observed. In addition, the protein trimer is stabilized by 30 pairs (10 on each 150 subunit) of disulfide bonds (Fig. S4 ). The S trimer shows a dome-like shape, 151 with three S1 heads forming a crown-like structure and sitting on top of a 152 trimeric S2 stalk (Fig. 1D, 1E and Movie S1). The trimer spike has a length of 153 143.2 Å from S1 to S2 and a width of 111.3 Å and 61.4 Å at S1 and S2, 154 respectively (Fig. 1E) . Three S1-CTDs are located at the top center of the S 155 trimer arranged as a small triangle, whereas three S1-NTDs are located on the 156 lower and outer side of S1-CTDs arranged as a big triangle. This architecture, 157 i.e., CTD sandwiched by its own NTD and the adjacent NTD, comes into being 158 one side of the big triangle (Fig. 1F) . The cleavage site of S1 and S2 subunits 159 locates between residues 544 (Val) and 545 (Arg). The central helicase N 160 (CH-N) and C (CH-C) of S2 from each subunit form a six-helix bundle in the 161 core of S trimer. Heptad repeats N (HR-N) contains four helices connected by 162 three loops locked between the S1 and S2 subunit at the outside of the S2 163 stalk, while part of the HR-C is missed in the structure (Fig. 1G) . Each 164 monomeric subunit of S1 contains two major domains, S1-NTD and S1-CTD 165 which are used to bind attachment sialic acid receptors or protein receptors 166 and play a key role in the coronavirus entry, and two subdomains, SD1 and 167 SD2 whose function are not very clear ( Fig. 1H-1I , Movie S1).

(H-I). Structures of S1-NTD (cyan) and S1-CTD (green), the putative RBM wrapped at the center of the crown-like trimer ( Fig. 2A) . Accordingly, the 205 geometry of SADS-CoV S resembles the prefusion structures of other α-and 206 δ-genera with the intra-subunit packing mode and is more compact than those 207 of β-and γ-genera that use the cross-subunit packing mode ( Fig. 2A-2E) . 208 Interestingly, although SADS-CoV belongs to the α-genera, its spike protein 209 doesn't have the domain 0 which is commonly found in other α-genera CoVs, 210 e.g., NL63-CoV and PEDV (Fig. 2F-G) [23].

Different from the receptor-binding inactive state of these structures 212 whose all three CTDs in "lying down" positions ( Fig. 2A-2E) , previous study 213 captured several β-CoVs S which contain one or two, even all three CTDs in CTDs are in the "lying down" position, it is not possible to bind ACE2 due to the 218 partial binding sites are hided and steric clashes between binding factors. This 219 kind of conformation represents an inactive state (Fig. 2H) . The CTDs in our 220 structure keep a "lying down" state and the receptor-binding moieties are 221 partially concealed. It needs to "stand up" on the spike trimer and release the 222 steric clash for efficient receptor binding. The linker between CTDs and S1 223 subdomains workes as a hinge to facilitate the conformation change of CTDs 224 from "lying down" to "stand up", furthermore, transit the receptor-binding 225 inactive state to active state (Fig. 2F) . 226 It is noteworthy that stronger interactions in SADS-CoV spike trimer may 227 obstacle conformational change and dissociation of S1-CTD in prefusion 228 process (Fig. S5) . Moreover, to probe the intrinsic mobility of the CTD/RBD of model was initially generated using the "lying down" state structure (Fig. S6) . 233 The center-of-mass distances between each two CTDs/RBDs across the 234 simulations ( Fig. S6) indicated that all the three CTDs/RBDs were stabilized in 235 a "lying down" state similar to the structure observed in this study, i.e. the 236 distance differences calculated from simulations and crystal structure were 237 less than 5 Å. Although we did not observe apparent expending of the 238 CTDs/RBDs from a "lying down" state to a "stand up" state during the 239 simulations, it did not rule out the co-existence of the two states in the apo form.

Because such large conformational transition may happen over long time 241 scales (ms to s), far beyond the simulations performed here. Taken together, 242 these simulation results may explain the homogeneity of SADS-CoV spike 243 observed in our 3D classification and that the different S1-CTD conformations 244 are invisible in our results (Fig. 1B) . 245 For the NTDs, the core structure consists of two six-stranded antiparallel 246 β-sheet layers stacked together which takes the same galectin fold as human 247 galectins and the NTDs from the other genera. Besides the core structure, 248 NTD of SADS-CoV S1 also has a loop (residues 133-150) formed as a partial 249 ceiling-like structure that resembles the partial ceiling of γ-coronavirus rather 250 than the other α-and δ-coronavirus which do not have a ceiling-like structure, 251 or the β-coronavirus which has a reinforced ceiling-like structure (Fig. 2I-M) . 252 Based on the structural similarity between the NTDs from four different CoVs 253 genera, the sugar-binding site in SADS-CoV S1-NTD might also be located in 254 the pocket formed between the core structure and the partial ceiling (Fig. 2I) . 255 Compared with other CoVs, the structure of the subdomain under the core 256 domain of SADS-CoV S1-NTD has the same situation of the partial ceiling-like 257 structure (Fig. 2I-M) . Previous study gave the idea that NTDs from the four 258 genera form an evolutionary spectrum in the order of α-, δ-, γ-and β-genera, 259 with α-CoVs NTD probably being the most ancestral [24] . Our structure has 260 also unexpectedly consisted with this conclusion. Furthermore, we propose 261 that the structural evolution of SADS-CoV S1-NTD is more likely to located 262 between the other α-CoVs, δ-CoVs and γ-CoVs. 263 For the CTDs, despite there are dramatic sequential differences between 264 SADS-CoV S1-CTD and other CTDs, all of them share the similar structural 265 topology [24] (Fig. 2N-R) . Unlike the other CTDs of α-CoVs and δ-CoVs which 266 have a more compact core β-sandwich structure containing two β-sheet layers, 267 our CTD resembles the γ-and β-CoVs which just has one layer β-sheet and 268 several α-helix and coil structures with a loose packing (Fig. 2N-R) . of CTDs as its receptor binding motif (RBM). As a result, we propose that 272 SADS-CoV also uses these loops on the CTD as its RBM (Fig. 2N-P) . 273 Moreover, the CTDs of γ-CoVs evolves to get extended loops and the β-CoVs The CTDs from different genera give an evolutionary spectrum, using α-and 282 δ-CoVs CTDs as ancestral, γ-CoVs CTDs as the transitional structure and 283 β-CoVs CTDs the downstream structure, but the evolutionary direction could 284 go either way [24] . Hence, we propose that the SADS-CoV S1-CTD located 285 between the other α-, δ-CoVs and β-CoVs CTDs on the evolutionary spectrum 286 (Fig. 2N-R) . (H). Structures of S1 monomer from SARS-CoV. The left panel shows the S1 301 subunit in a "lying down" state, while the right panel shows the S1 subunit in a 302 "stand up" state. The conformational change of the subunits from "lying down" (Table S1 ). In addition, the Dali analysis of CTD 332 showed that SADS-CoV S CTD is relatively poorly conserved with β-CoVs, as (Table S2) . Taken together, these results are 336 consistent with that of the sequence alignment. (NL63-CoV)-ACE2 (Fig. 3B-3D ) and the CTDs of SARS-CoV-2, SARS-CoV 350 and SADS-CoV (Fig. 3E) . Surprisingly, although SARS-CoV-2, SARS-CoV 351 and SADS-CoV CTD do not share significant sequence homology and belong 352 to different family of CoVs (Fig. 3A) , they share roughly identical organization 353 and core folding (Fig. 3E) . Notably, SADS-CoV uses the variant loop region as 354 its RBM which is consist with the insertion domain of SARS-CoV and 355 SARS-CoV-2 CTDs that is formed by two β sheets and several loops (Fig. 3E) . 356 Meanwhile, compared with the β-CoVs SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV, the On one hand, the SADS-CoV S has a classical compact structure as other 380 α-CoVs, which uses the intra-subunit packing mode ( Fig. 2A-2B) . As a result, shows that there are fifty N-linked glycans spreading over the surface of each 397 S subunit. They are mainly located on the surface of S1 rather than on S2 like 398 HCoV-NL63 (Fig. 4A) . In contrast to that HCoV-NL63 S evades host immune 399 surveillance mainly by glycan shielding its S2 epitopes, SADS-CoV spike 400 appears to evade host immune surveillance mainly by glycan shielding its S1 401 epitopes [31]. In addition, unlike the other α-coronavirus and δ-coronavirus 402 whose putative sugar-binding sites are surrounded by glycans, most of the 403 SADS-CoV N-linked glycosylation sites are located on the CTD (Fig. 4A-4B) . 404 As a result, the putative sugar-binding sites on the NTD are shielded, not by 405 glycans, but by the partial ceiling-like structure on the top of the core structure.

FIGREF0.text: Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) in 2012, Swine Acute Diarrhea 51 Syndrome (SADS) in 2017, and the latest 2019 outbreak of human-infecting 52 virulent strain of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 53 (SARS-CoV-2) have claimed a large number of human lives and livestock.

FIGREF2.text: 57 positive-sense, 27-32 kb in length single-strand RNA (+ssRNA) [4]. CoVs 58 have a place with the subfamily Coronavirinae, family Coronaviridae, order 59 Nidovirales, and grouped into four genera for example alpha (α), beta (β), both 60 CoVs infecting mammals, gamma (γ) CoVs infecting birds, and delta (δ) CoVs 61 infecting mammals and birds [5]. CoVs bring about subclinical or respiratory 62 syndrom, central nervous system (CNS) infections, gastrointestinal ailments in 63 humans, and animals [6-8]. These infections are accountable for 30% of the 64 respiratory illnesses, atypical pneumonia [3, 9] and show a tendency for 65 interspecies transmission which happened rather often during CoV evolution 66 and shaped the diversity of CoVs [10]. 67 Porcine CoVs are chief health concerns of the pigs and are 68 considerable enteric and respiratory infections causing agents of swine. A 69 novel CoV instigating swine acute diarrhea syndrome (SADS) emerged since 70 August 2016. It is associated with HKU2-related Rhinolophus bat CoV with 71 death rate up to 90% in piglets 5 days or younger in Guangdong territory pig 72 breeding farms and accounted for the killing of around 25,000 piglets [11]. 73 SADS-CoV has a position with the class α-CoVs, and it is enveloped +ssRNA 74 virus [7, 12, 13]. The intracellular entry of SADS-CoV relies on a precise 75 interaction amid virion and the host cell. The disease is initiated by the 76 interplay of the viral particle with specific cell surface S trimmer [14]. 77 CoVs from various genera display evident serotypes, for the most part, 78 because of the dissimilarity of their envelope-anchored diversified S proteins. 79 S protein is of around 1300 amino acids, has a place with class I viral 80 combination protein, including SARS-CoVs, human immunodeficiency virus 81 (HIV) envelop glycoprotein 160 (gp160), influenza virus haemagglutinin (HA), 82 paramyxovirus F and Ebola virus glycoprotein [15]. The S protein includes 83 three sections: a large ectodomain, a single-pass transmembrane anchor, and 84 a small intracellular tail. The ectodomain comprises of a N-terminal 85

FIGREF3.text: 98 utilize aminopeptidase N (APN) as its receptor, SARS-CoV, HCoV-NL63, and 99 SARS-CoV-2 employ angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), and 100 MERS-CoV ties to dipeptidyl-peptidase 4 (DPP4). However, receptor 101 investigation of SADS-CoV demonstrated that none of the known CoV 102 receptors, i.e., APN, ACE2, and DPP4, is crucial for cell entry that shows the 103 divergence and significance of S protein in SADS-CoV infection [11]. Along 104 these lines, contemplating the clinical indications of this advancing virus, there 105

FIGREF4.text: 117 the receptor of SADS-CoV. The structural alignment suggests that SADS-CoV 118 S is located between α-CoV and β-CoV clade. Hence, our results extend the 119 understanding of critical structural and evolutionary insights into SADS-CoV S 120 comprising the CTD/RBD essential for receptor recognition and viral entry.

FIGREF5.text: This study provides the epidemiological and evolutionary information of this122 novel virus in China which is deteriorating economically important swine 123 industry, and highlights the urgency to develop effective measures to control 124 SADS-CoV.

FIGREF6.text: to investigate the role of SADS-CoV S in its invasion, we aimed to 131 solve the high-resolution structure of SADS-CoV S. SADS-CoV S ectodomain 132 was secretory expressed and purified from media of insert cells after 3 days of 133 infection by baculovirus. A fusion peptide of General control protein GCN4 at 134 the C-terminal end of S was used to promote the protein forms a trimer [23] 135 (Fig. 1A). The size-exclusion chromatography (SEC) result showed that the 136 protein sample is a trimer in solution and the purity more than 95% examined 137in SDS-PAGE analysis(Fig. S1A, S1B). The protein displayed high 138 homogeneity in cryo-EM screening, and was then diluted to 0.63 mg ml -1 for 139 data collection. Cryo-EM micrograph movies were collected on a Gatan K2 140 direct electron detector mounted on an FEI Titan Krios electron microscope 141(Fig. S2). Following reference-free 2D classification of the spike protein, we 142 determined a three-dimensional structure of the SADS-CoV S trimer at 3.55 Å 143 resolution judged by the gold-standard Fourier shell correlation (FSC) criterion 144 of 0.143(Fig. 1B, 1CandTable 1). The resolved atomic structure of prefusion 145 SADS-CoV S ectodomain covers almost all of the key structure elements as 146 shown inFig. 1Aexcept residues 81-101 of NTD and residues 999-1068 of

Schematic drawing of SADS-CoV S. S1: receptor-binding subunit. S2: 177 membrane-fusion subunit. NTD: N-terminal domain of S1. S1-CTD: C-terminal 178 domain of S1. SD1-3: subdomain 1-3. FP: fusion peptide. CH-N and CH-C: 179 central helices N and C. HR-N and HR-C: heptad repeats N and C. Tag: GCN4 180 trimerization tag followed by His 6 tag. 181 (D). Final cryo-EM density map of SADS-CoV S colored according to the local 182 resolution. 183 (E). Cryo-EM structure of SADS-CoV S in the prefusion conformation. Each of 184 the monomeric subunit is colored in green, cyan and magenta, respectively. 185 (F). Same as (E) but the dome is rotated 90 degrees to show the top view of 186 the trimer, the CTDs arrange as a small triangle and is indicated by a black 187 triangle, and the two adjacent NTDs sandwich one CTD to form one side of a 188 big triangle which is indicated by gray triangle. 189 (G). Cryo-EM structure of SADS-CoV S monomeric subunit. The structural 190 elements are colored in the same way as in panel (A).

FIGREF10.text: of coronavirus spike protein 195 The S from all the four different genera of the coronavirus packs a 196 crown-like structure by three monomeric subunits which can be divided into 197 two packing modes: the cross-subunit packing mode and the intra-subunit 198 packing mode [24]. Our SADS-CoV S structure takes an intra-subunit 199 quaternary packing mode where the NTD and CTD from the same subunits 200 pack together by head to head. In SADS-CoV S, the three NTDs from different 201 subunits are located at the vertices of the big triangle formed by the S1 202 subunits and sandwich the CTDs to the center of the triangle. As a result, the 203 putative receptor-binding moieties located on the top of CTDs are also 204

FIGREF14.text: 274 obtains an insertion domain which contains RBM under the host immune 275 pressure, these receptor-binding moieties also located on the top of core 276 domain (Fig. 2Q-R). Previous studies have shown that the core structures are 277 two layers β-sandwiches for α-and δ-CoVs CTDs, weakened β-sandwiches 278 for γ-CoVs CTDs, and single β-sheet layer for β-CoVs CTDs. The RBMs are 279 three short discontinuous loops for α-and δ-CoVs CTDs, two reinforced loops 280 for γ-CoVs CTDs, and a single continuous insertion domain for β-CoVs CTDs.

FIGREF19.text: between the S of SADS-CoV, SARS-CoV and 319 SARS-CoV-2 320 The phylogenetic analysis based on the whole genome and N gene of 321 eight SADS-CoVs and other CoVs showed that all the sequence of 322 SADS-CoVs clustered with bat coronavirus HKU2 to form a well defined 323 branch and belong to the α-genera [28]. However, interestingly, the 324 phylogenetic analysis of the S genes showed that the S gene cluster can be 325 divided into two groups: α-CoV-1 and α-CoV-2. All of the SADS-CoVs and bat 326 coronavirus HKU2 belong to α-CoV1 which group with the β-CoVs to form the 327 half evolutionary branch of CoVs, whereas the other α-CoVs cluster to the 328 α-CoV-2 [28, 29]. The structural alignment of the SADS-CoV S trimer by Dali 329 analysis (http://ekhidna2.biocenter.helsinki.fi/dali/) implies that SADS-CoV S 330 has a relatively conservation with that of β-CoVs, as reflected by the generally 331 high Z-scores and high RMSD

FIGREF20.text: 333 reflected by the generally low Z-scores and high RMSD, although it shares 334 roughly identical core folding with other β-CoVs, i.e., HKU9, SARS-CoV, 335 MERS-CoV, HKU1 and OC43

FIGREF21.text: Based on the phylogenetic analysis, we compared the CTDs of338 SADS-CoV, SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 by the sequence and structure. The 339 whole SADS-CoV S ectodomain is only approximately 30% sequence identity 340 when compared with the SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2, which obstructs 341 structural alignment between SADS-CoV, SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2. 342 Especially there is no significant homologous CoV S CTD found in the PDB 343 when the SADS-CoV S CTD sequence as the inquiry. Interestingly, the 344 SADS-CoV S CTD is smaller (about 130 residues) than other CoV CTD (about 345 170 residues) (Fig. 3A). To further investigate the differences between the S of 346 SADS and other CoVs, and deduce the hypothesis of SADS pathogenic 347 mechanisms, we focused on CTD and performed structural alignments using 348 the complexes of CTD (SARS-CoV-2)-ACE2, CTD (SARS-CoV)-ACE2, CTD 349

FIGREF22.text: NL63 also use its loops to bind ACE2. Although the loops of SADS-CoV 358 and NL63 CTDs share structural similarity, SADS-CoV cannot use the ACE2 359 as its receptor. These features imply that both of the variant sequence and the 360 local structure of these loops are combined to determine the receptor binding Comparison of RBD domain of SADS-CoV, SARS-CoV, and 364 SARS-CoV-2. 365 (A). The structure of SADS-CoV S 378 provides some hints on the immune evasion strategies of SADS-CoV.

FIGREF24.text: 381 this kind of architecture can maximally reduce the surface area of the spike 382 protein to the immune system. Moreover, all of the NTDs and CTDs in a "lay 383 down" station (closed conformation) can further reduce immune pressure (Fig. 384 2F). Nevertheless, the NTDs and CTDs still have the chance to expose for 385 receptor binding. Furthermore, they can also be selected as single-or 386 two-RBD system [30]. Based on the structural alignment of these structures, 387 we speculate that SADS-CoV use the two-RBD system for which the NTD is 388 used as the attachment receptor binding domain and the CTD is used as the 389 protein receptor binding domain. Upon infecting host cells, S1-CTD would 390 need to switch to an open conformation ("stand up") to render the putative 391 RBM loops accessible to the host receptor. This closed-to-open mechanism can minimize the exposure of the putative RBM loops to the other hand, as one of the immune evasion strategy, masking of 395 epitopes by glycan shielding is usual in coronavirus evolution [31]. FIGREF26.text: Cryo-EM structure of SADS-CoV S has been deposited into EMDB with 483 accession numbers of EMD-30071. Coordinates and structure factors have 484 been deposited in the Protein Data Bank (PDB)

TABREF0.text: Data collection and refinement statistics.and divided into aliquots, flash frozen in liquid nitrogen.Cryo-EM sample preparation and data acquisitionPurified spike protein was diluted to 0.63 mg ml-1 with buffer containing 20 mM HEPES pH 7.5, 100 mM NaCl and 2 mM DTT. A 4 µl volume of sample was applied to glow-discharged Quantifoil copper grid and vitrified by plunge freezing in a liquid ethane using a Vitrobot Mark with a blotting time of 3 s.Data collection was performed on a Titan Krios microscope operated at 300 kV and equipped with a field emission gun, a Gatan GIF Quantum energy filter and a Gatan K2 Summit direct electron camera in super-resolution mode, at CBI-IBP. The calibrated magnification was 130,000× in EF TEM mode, corresponding to a pixel size of 1.04 Å. The automated software SerialEM was used to collect 1,000 movies at a defocus range of between 1.8 and 2.3 µm.Each exposure (10 s exposure time) comprised 32 sub-frames amounting to a Micrograph movie stacks were corrected for beam-induced motion usingMotionCor2 [33]. The contrast transfer function parameters for each dose weighting image were determined with Gctf [34]. Particles were initially auto picked with Gautomatch without template and extracted with a 256-pixel by 256-pixel box. Reference-free 2D-class average was performed using RELION 464 [35], and the well-resolved 2D averages were subjected to another iteration particle auto picking as template with Gautomatch. After iterative 2D-class average in RELION, only particles with best-resolved 2D averages were selected for initial model generation and 3D classification using RELION. The classes with identical detailed features were merged for further auto-refinement with a sphere mask, and post processed with 3-pixel extension and 3-pixel fall-off around the entire molecule, to produce the final density map with an overall resolution of 3.55 Å. Chimera and PyMOL 472 (https://pymol.org/) were used for graphical visualization [36].Ab initio modelling of the spike protein was performed in Coot[37], using structure predictions calculated by Phyre2 [38], the partial structure modeled by EMBuilder[39], and the reference model (PDB: 5X58). Map refinement was carried out using Phenix.real_space_refine [40], with secondary structure and Ramachandran restraints. Cryo-EM data collection, refinement and validation statistics were listed inTable 1.
